awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms of Multicellular Self-Organization in Myxococcus Xanthus
awd_abstract_narration:
This project engages a collaborating team of experimental microbiologists, computational biologists, and mathematicians to understand the mechanisms by which soil bacterium Myxococcus xanthus aggregates into multicellular mounds in response to starvation. Using mathematical and biological approaches, the team will uncover interactions that control different stages of developmental self-organization: (1) pre-aggregation cell alignment and formation of cellular streams; (2) formation and growth of initial aggregates; and (3) aggregate coarsening, dispersal, and pulsing. This project is expected to elucidate some of the general mechanisms behind the collective behavior of motile cells in other organisms and to develop widely applicable mathematical approaches. Transition from single cells to multicellularity is fundamentally important to increase understanding of many pathogenic bacteria and to elucidate self-organization in more complex systems. Even though individual bacterial cells are considered to function independently and to be autonomous, many bacterial populations will act collectively, communicating, moving and self-organizing into multicellular structures.  M. xanthus is a great model system for studying biological self-organization: its cells function fine alone, but cooperate to form variety of distinct, dynamic patterns depending on environmental conditions. However, the mechanisms of these behaviors are currently not fully understood. Broader impacts of the project will be further enhanced by training opportunities for participating students. Solving complex biological problems requires a new generation of life scientists with cross-disciplinary training in both experimental and computational methods. This research will provide those training opportunities for all participants, facilitated by close interactions such as joint meetings and trainee collaborations.  

This project focuses on solving one of the fundamental problems of modern developmental biology: how individual cells self-organize into multicellular structures. In particular, the goal of the research is to uncover mechanisms controlling the developmental program of a biofilm formed by M. xanthus. This soil bacterium is tractable and has a relatively simple genome and as such is an excellent model system to develop novel mathematical models and experimentally test their predictions. Under starvation, M. xanthus cells coordinate their movement in space and time, bringing tens of thousands of cells together into multicellular aggregates to differentiate into spores. This model of prokaryotic development is experimentally tractable and shares many of the complexities that are ubiquitous in developmental systems. With a combination of mathematical modeling approaches and quantitative experiments, this project will uncover the interactions and signaling mechanisms that control three distinct stages of developmental self-organization. To this end, the research builds on the previously fruitful methodology to connect these interactions with the observed population phenotypes. The emphasis of the mathematical component of this research is on the advancement of agent-based and kinetic models that go beyond the existing, oversimplified models of the phenomena that postulate and analyze a single mechanism for self-organization. The resulting predictions will be tested experimentally using genetic or environmental perturbations. Broader impacts include developing novel and widely applicable methodology to understand multicellular patterns, cross-disciplinary training for participating students, and educational and outreach activities based on the research results and methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project engaged a collaborating team of experimental microbiologists, computational biologists, and mathematicians to understand the mechanisms by which soil bacterium M. xanthus aggregates into multicellular mounds in response to starvation. Using mathematical and biological approaches, the team uncovered interactions that control different stages of developmental self-organization: (1) pre-aggregation cell alignment and formation of cellular streams; (2) formation and growth of initial aggregates; and (3) aggregate coarsening, dispersal, and pulsing.

Intellectual merit: The research has provided several key insights into the mechanisms of M. xanthus pattern formation. In particular, we pursued the research directions outlined below.

1. We developed a model for the nematic alignment of rod-like cells interacting through binary collisions.  Under the assumption that each collision results in a small change to a rod's orientation, we derived the Fokker-Planck equation for the evolution of the cellular density. Larger changes in orientation occur over the course of sequential collisions. We showed the relation between our Fokker-Planck equation and existing phenomenological models of cell alignment in the relevant asymptotic regime.

2. Experimental evidence suggests that M. xanthus follows motion with reversal times which are distributed non-exponentially. Thus, we analyzed a prototype agent-based model with non-exponential reversal times and derived the corresponding kinetic equation. We demonstrated that models with non-exponential reversal times result in more confined aggregates and faster aggregation times.

3. We developed a second Boltzmann-type 2D kinetic model for bacterial alignment when cell re-orientation is asymmetric, with the colliding cell reorienting to align with the struck cell. We demonstrated that in certain parameter regimes, there is a discrepancy between the agent-based simulations and the kinetic model due to the loss of statistical independence. This implies that asymmetric alignment produces correlations between cells which need to be taken into account by the kinetic model for the cell’s density.

4. We considered kinetic models for the motion of myxobacteria that take into account cell alignment, orientation diffusion, and cell reversals with and without bias due to cell signaling. In the motion regime when the rate of reversals is larger compared to rates of other types of cell motility, we derived novel kinetic equations describing effectively uni-directional diffusion which, in the case of the chemotaxis, depends on the gradient of the chemical signal. In the same paper, we provided a formal mathematical method of constructing solutions of corresponding initial-boundary value problems for the kinetic PDEs. Our approach is based on the theory of kinetic averaging approach from the gas dynamics.

5. In collaboration with another UH team, we developed large deviations framework for analyzing rare evolutionary events in large bacterial populations. Such rare events describe, for instance, the emergence of genotypes with lower fitness, but with a higher degree of adaptivity. Such evolutionary events are rare and cannot be computed using straightforward Monte-Carlo simulations. Large-deviations theory provides a framework for deriving explicit expression for computing most-likely evolutionary trajectories describing rare events. We also implemented the gradient descent algorithms in the space of evolutionary paths for faster computations.

 

Broader impacts: The methods and models we developed are expected to be generally applicable for understanding the collective behavior of cells, bacteria, and viruses.  The project supported  1 graduate student (successfully defended PhD in 2022). One postdoctoral associate working at Rice U. on this project collaborated closely with the UH team; he obtained a tenure-track position at the  San Jose State University.

Publications: 2 published, 4 pre-prints (papers submitted), and 1 more is in preparation.

Presentations: members of the UH team gave 6 talks at various conferences and workshops.
